intro: Richardia humistrata, commonly known as the swamp mallow, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and it thrives in moist, sandy soils. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. Richardia humistrata plays an important role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems and providing habitat for various insects and small aquatic organisms.
